html:
For a Reuters live blog on U.S., UK and European stock markets, click LIVE/ or type LIVE/ in a news window

  • Tyson Foods firms on upbeat quarterly results
  • Peloton up on reports of potential buyout offer from Amazon
  • Indexes down: Dow 0.22%, S&P 0.35%, Nasdaq 0.42%

Adds comment; updates prices

By Bansari Mayur Kamdar

Feb 7 (Reuters) - U.S. stock indexes reversed course to slip on Monday as markets digested mixed quarterly results from megacaps Amazon and Facebook owner Meta Platforms last week, while Peloton jumped on media reports of interest from potential buyers including Amazon.

Seven of the 11 major S&P 500 sectors declined, with S&P 500 communication services .SPLRCL dropping nearly 2% and leading losses.

Meta Platforms FB.O fell 4.3%, extending losses for the third straight session after its record plunge last week on a bleak forecast. (Full Story)

On the other hand, Amazon.com Inc AMZN.O rose 1.4%, extending gains after expanding its market capitalization by around $190 billion on Friday on the back of blowout earnings. (Full Story)

Shares of other tech titans Apple Inc AAPL.O, Microsoft Corp MSFT.O and Google-owner Alphabet Inc GOOGL.O also dropped.

"These huge price swings in very well-known and widely analyzed companies are a bit unnerving as far as investors' sense of predictability of lesser stocks and the market in general," said Louis Navellier, chief investment officer for Navellier & Associates.

At 12:31 p.m. ET, the Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI was down 77.27 points, or 0.22%, at 35,012.47, the S&P 500 .SPX was down 15.74 points, or 0.35%, at 4,484.79, and the Nasdaq Composite .IXIC was down 59.68 points, or 0.42%, at 14,038.33.

U.S. stocks had opened higher on Monday, with meatpacker Tyson Foods Inc TSN.N climbing 10% to the top of the S&P 500 index after its first-quarter profit nearly doubled and surged past estimates on the back of higher prices. (Full Story)

Of the 278 companies in the S&P 500 that have posted earnings as of Friday, 78.4% reported above analysts' expectations, according to Refinitiv data.

"January spooked some of the dip buyers out of the market for a while and we're just now starting to see them come back, though the full-fledged 'buy the dip' mentality has cooled a bit," said Randy Frederick, managing director of trading and derivatives at Charles Schwab in Austin, Texas.

An unexpectedly strong jobs report last week spooked investors about aggressive policy tightening by the U.S. Federal Reserve, ahead of key inflation data for January that is due on Thursday. (Full Story)

Markets are now pricing in a one-in-three chance the Fed might hike by a full 50 basis points in March and the prospect of rates reaching 1.5% by year end. FEDWATCH

Peloton Interactive Inc PTON.O surged 16.3% on media reports that Amazon and Nike NKE.N are exploring potential buyout offers for the exercise bike maker. (Full Story)

Spirit Airlines Inc SAVE.N jumped 13.3% on rival Frontier Group Holdings' ULCC.O deal to buy the budget airline, lifting the S&P 1500 Airlines Index .SPCOMAIR by 2.1%. (Full Story)

U.S.-listed shares of China's Alibaba Group Holding BABA.N fell 6.3% after it registered an additional 1 billion American depositary shares. (Full Story)

Declining issues outnumbered advancers for a 1.09-to-1 ratio on the NYSE. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 1.03-to-1 ratio on the Nasdaq.

The S&P index recorded 15 new 52-week highs and five new lows, while the Nasdaq recorded 27 new highs and 71 new lows.


(Reporting by Bansari Mayur Kamdar and Devik Jain in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

(( BansariMayur.Kamdar@thomsonreuters.com ;))
